section.title: What can I do with StemCellMine?
section.para: StemCellMine is an integrated database of genomic, expression and protein data for Homo sapiens, Mus musculus, Monodelphis domestica and Canis familiaris with emphasize on Stem Cell research. Integrating data makes it possible to run sophisticated data mining queries that span domains of biological knowledge.
Enter any identifier or symbol in the search box on the StemCellMine home page to access summary pages and integrated tools. See FlyMine webpage for Tutorial 1 Tutorial 2.

Some examples:
for the Homo sapiens gene, type Ensembl identifiers (eg. ENSG00000186445), HUGO identifiers, (eg. 29997), or any of its synonyms.
for proteins use UniProt identifiers or primary accessions (eg. COX1_HUMAN, P00395).

StemCellMine presents data as 'aspects', with each aspect providing a 'view' of a particular type of data (for example Gene Expression or Protein Interactions). Use the aspect icons on the StemCellMine home page to run a predefined template query or to build your own query (see below). Certain template queries, as well as the QueryBuilder itself, allow you to perform searches that span more than one aspect.

A number of specific queries have been predefined. These template queries range from fairly simple queries to retrieve a particular type of data to more complex queries that span the different types of data availbale in StemCellMine. More template queries will be added as StemCellMine develops and we welcome suggestions. Find lists of predefined template queries on each aspect page or use the Template Search box on the StemCellMine home page and in the top menu on every page. Tutorial 3

Advanced users can use a flexible query interface to construct their own data mining queries across the multiple integrated data sources, to modify existing template queries or to create your own template queries. Access the StemCellMine QueryBuilder via the StemCellMine home page or choose a query starting point on an aspect page.

All queries in StemCellMine can be performed on lists (or 'bags') that you create yourself. Bags can be created by typing or pasting in a list of identifiers, or uploading a file containing the list. Data from previous queries can also be saved into a bag using the boxes displayed underneath the query results. Saved bags of data can be used to constrain new queries, perform logical operations and can be exported.
You can save your bags, queries and templates between sessions by creating an account using the 'Log in' box in the top menu on every page.
See flymine webpage for short tutorials and user manual for more information.
